Authors:
Steven A. Trewick, Simon Hills, Michael Richard Gemmell,
Mary Morgan-Richards
Title:
Phylogenetic analysis of the New Zealand olive shells is
consistent with Punctuated Equilibrium
Journal:
Journal of Zoological Systematics and Evolutionary
Research
Abstract:
The olive shells of the genus Amalda are a speciose group
of neogastropod mollusc with an extensive distribution. In New Zealand
there is an excellent fossil record and accordingly three endemic
species have been cited as providing support for morphological stasis, a
prerequisite for punctuated equilibrium. Geographic isolation of the New
Zealand fauna reduces the possibility of past dispersal of related
species, events that might be mistaken for speciation in the fossil
record. However, the evolutionary relationships of the New Zealand
Amalda species have not been studied. The possibility that New Zealand
Amalda species evolved in isolation is examined here using long DNA
sequences from both mitochondrial (whole mitogenome) and nuclear (45S
rDNA) markers from 11 Amalda species collected from New Zealand and
around the world. Our inferred phylogenies from the mitochondrial and
nuclear DNA sequences cannot refute the hypothesis that New Zealand
Amalda are monophyletic, although current sampling represents a fraction
of the global diversity of Amalda species. The current classification of
the New Zealand Amalda into two subgenera is not supported. We estimated
the timing of cladogenesis within the New Zealand taxa and resolved
dates compatible with the fossil record for extant species and
consistent with punctuated equilibrium.
